conclusion: Objects A and B are initially held in the air above the table.
When released, gravity pulls objects A and B straight downward.
Objects A and B fall until they reach the level of the tabletop, where objects C, D, E, and F are already positioned.
Objects C and D sit directly beneath object A, and objects E and F sit directly beneath object B.
Each falling object (A and B) will strike the obstacle (C, D, E, F) that is in its vertical path.

Once contact occurs, object A will come to rest against objects C and D, and object B will come to rest against objects E and F (or whichever of the two it meets first), stopping further downward motion.
Final answer: A lands on C–D, and B lands on E–F; both falling objects simply stop when they hit the first tabletop objects in their way.
